statement.p:
For both parts of this exercise, give a geometric description of sets of the vectors \bvec and include a sketch.
For which vectors \bvec in \real^2 is the equation
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp -6 \\ -2 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right] \xvec = \bvec consistent?
For which vectors \bvec in \real^2 is the equation
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp -6 \\ -2 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] \xvec = \bvec consistent?

li.p:
\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp -6 \\ -2 \amp 4 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]
so \bvec must be on the line defined by \twovec{3}{-2}.

\left[\begin{array}{rr} 3 \amp -6 \\ -2 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]
so \bvec can be any vector in \real^2.
\bvec must be a scalar multiple of \twovec{3}{-2}.
\bvec can be any vector in \real^2.

statement.p:
Consider the following matrices:
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 3 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp 3 \amp 7 \\ 3 \amp -2 \amp 1 \amp 5 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ \end{array}\right],~~~ B = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 3 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 4 \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \\ 3 \amp -2 \amp 1 \amp 3 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] . Do the columns of A span \real^4? Do the columns of B span \real^4?

li.p:
The reduced row echelon form of A is
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 3 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp 3 \amp 7 \\ 3 \amp -2 \amp 1 \amp 5 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 3 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]
so the columns of A do not span \real^4.

The reduced row echelon form of B is
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 3 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 4 \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp 3 \amp -1 \\ 3 \amp -2 \amp 1 \amp 3 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]
so the columns of B span \real^4.

answer.p: The columns of A do not span \real^4. The columns of B do.

statement.p: The following observation will be helpful in this exercise. If we want to find a solution to the equation AB\xvec = \bvec, we could first find a solution to the equation A\yvec = \bvec and then find a solution to the equation B\xvec = \yvec.

Suppose that A is a 3\times 4 matrix whose columns span \real^3 and B is a 4\times 5 matrix. In this case, we can form the product AB.
What is the shape of the product AB?
Can you guarantee that the columns of AB span \real^3?
If you know additionally that the span of the columns of B is \real^4, can you guarantee that the columns of AB span \real^3?

li.p: AB is a 3\times5 matrix.

No. Since the columns of A span \real^3, then the equation A\yvec=\bvec has a solution \yvec for every vector \bvec. However, we may not be able to solve the equation B\xvec=\yvec if the columns of B do not span \real^4.

Yes. If we are given a vector \bvec in \real^3, we can find a vector \yvec such that A\yvec = \bvec since the columns of A span \real^3. Since the columns of B span \real^4, we can find a vector \xvec such that B\xvec=\yvec. Then AB\xvec = \bvec, which means that B is the span of the columns of AB.

What can you say about the pivot positions of A?

li.p: Since the solution is unique, each column of A must have a pivot position. Since there are also 12 rows, each row must have a pivot position as well. This means that the row reduced echelon form of A is the identity matrix.
Since there is a pivot position in every row, the span of the columns of A is \real^{12}.

statement.p: As defined in this section, the span of a set of vectors is generated by taking all possible linear combinations of those vectors. This exercise will demonstrate the fact that the span can also be realized as the solution space to a linear system.

We will consider the vectors
\vvec_1=\threevec{1}{0}{-2}, \vvec_2=\threevec{2}{1}{0}, \vvec_3=\threevec{1}{1}{2}
Is every vector in \real^3 in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}? If not, describe the span.
To describe \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} as the solution space of a linear system, we will write
\bvec=\threevec{a}{b}{c} . If \bvec is in \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}, then the linear system corresponding to the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp a \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp b \\ -2\amp 0 \amp 2 \amp c \\ \end{array}\right]
must be consistent. This means that a pivot cannot occur in the rightmost column. Perform row operations to put this augmented matrix into a triangular form. Now identify an equation in a, b, and c that tells us when there is no pivot in the rightmost column. The solution space to this equation describes \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}.
In this example, the matrix formed by the vectors \left[\begin{array}{rrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\vvec_3 \\ \end{array}\right] has two pivot positions. Suppose we were to consider another example in which this matrix had had only one pivot position. How would this have changed the linear system describing \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}?

li.p:
Finding the reduced row echelon form
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]
shows that \vvec_3 is a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2. Therefore, \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} is the plane defined by \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
In that case, there would be two equations involving the variables a, b, and c, and the solution space would be a line.
\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} is the plane defined by \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
There would be two equations involving the variables a, b, and c.
